Professor, it strikes me as strange that, for someone who is part of academia and thus presumptively a champion of academic freedom, you are so afraid of people who don't agree with you.

Rather than tell us what you think is wrong with Mr. Goklany's paper, instead you attack his affiliations, obviously thinking that everyone will assume from those that his paper is no good. Well, that might work in academia but there are people out there who will give someone a fair hearing regardless of his pedigree.

If you're so sure that some college freshmen could "intellectually and factually dismantle Goklany's paper", then why don't you get a couple of them to submit a critique on this blog. Or you could submit one yourself. Have you even read the paper?

You complain about the "idealogical bent" of the author. This is funny. As one of the more ideologically transparent commenters on this blog, suggesting that someone with a point of view other than yours should be disqualified is rich indeed.

You wonder if Mr. Revkin simply wants to create controversy. How, by assuming that there are two sides to every issue? Peabody Coal is a huge energy provider that's going to be around for a long time. Maybe we'd all be better off if we knew more about them or understood why they have been successful.

In reply to Mr. Spalding Craft:

First, in my first post I did describe what I perceive to be faults of Goklany's paper. However, it is very difficult to be comprehensive with an imposed 1500 character limitation. If the limitation were not there I would be glad to respond more substantively.

Second, the issue is not freedom of expression, diverse viewpoints, etc. I value all of these. As I pointed out in my response(s), the problem is with someone whose work is affiliated so extensively with well–known conservative think tanks, i.e., ideological skeptics. If you (or Mr. Revkin) think that the conservative think tanks mentioned are reputable and credible in their work on climate change then we do have fundamental disagreements.

All I am saying is that Mr. Revkin probably could have found someone with credentials not so closely affiliated with the right wing conservative skeptic think tanks. The point is reaching for the best person one can get to comment on the topic at hand. And, I might add, the issues of the paper far exceed electrical engineering even broadly defined. I am interested in credible and objective discourse, so my point was not whether I agreed with Dr. Goklany.

All of this was spelled out in my responses, so perhaps a more thorough rereading on your part would have made this apparent.

Dr. John Lemons
Emeritus Professor of Biology and Environmental Science
Department of Environmental Studies
University of New England
Biddeford, ME 04005

Andy, it seems you are interested (once again) in generating unnecessary controversy. For example, with ample space students in my first–year class could intellectually and factually dismantle Goklany's paper. Beyond this, why "headline" someone on this issue rather than someone with less of an ideological bent and, perhaps, broader credentials than being an electrical engineer?

According to desmogblog.com, Goklany has:
1. Worked with numerous conservative think tanks that question AGW, including the Cato Institute and the Reason Foundation.
2. Been the Julian Simon Fellow at the Property and Environmental Research Center and a Fellow at the American Enterprise Institute (Both of Goklany's books were published by the Cato Institute)
3. Been affiliated with the Global Warming Policy Foundation and the International Policy Network (conservative climate groups). He also is a regular contributor to "Watts Up With That?"

Again, I believe the credibility of your blog would be enhanced if you had found a more accomplished and objective (judging from the organizations worked with/for) person who was well established in the conventional peer review literature to address the topic at hand.

It seems to me you intentionally are manufacturing controversy and, if so, why?

Dr. John Lemons
Emeritus Professor of Biology and Environmental Science
Department of Biology and Environmental Science
University of New England
Biddeford, ME

John, thanks for your service. I'm a 'Nam vet too, and I shoot regularly at a range, more than half of the guys I shoot with there are vets as well. Most of us still hunt, if we're able.
You will see some of the Travis Bickle types out there, blasting away at invisible bad guys and perhaps silently asking "you talking to me?!?", but I wouldn't go so far as to assume they represent a much larger group. I tend to agree most of them are not combat vets, but that's not to say some vets don't still have axes to grind. As a VA volunteer I talk to lots of them and you might be dismayed at the number that aren't as settled as you seem to be or I like to think I am. Nationally the VA's psych services are expanding faster than a rapid deployment unit, but they can't keep up with demand. Our armed forces use and depend on the macho aspects of violent video games to attract "talent". Simply put, the culture rewards this stereotype, and the military does little to unwind it when they're done with us.
AA, while effective for many, if far from a panacea. Many people in the profile you present are precisely those who don't function well in groups. Some just want to be left alone, a few get enraged at the feeling of being wronged, ignored or excluded, and explode. It goes deeper than military service, for what it's worth.

My father had a semi-automatic hunting rifle when I was a boy. He used it every Autumn when he and others went after deer and then elk. The rest of the time it sat in his closet, oiled, but collecting dust.

None of us thought of taking it, or any of the family's rifles down to the range to shoot thousands of rounds in practice. When Autumn came the rifles were zeroed with a few rounds and every year they did what they were designed to do: they killed game at ranges out to hundreds of yards. No one needed much practice to be that accurate.

After Vietnam I pretty much quit hunting. There was something about using a rifle on other human beings, and having it used against me, that sobbered me about being "human."

But I know the allure of the automatic weapon. I know it in myself, still, decades later, even though I haven't fired a weapon in 40 years.

I see it in other men, too, and primarily men. Women, yes, on occasion, but mostly men. Few of the men I know who spend hours on a range, shooting, fought in wars. Most of them are playing a part in their own play or in one in their society of friends.

The issue is one of psychology. I'm not a psychologist but of what I know of the science, and based on my long experience with the male of the species, I suspect it's the case world wide. I doubt that it can be changed by the individual, only by the will of "the society." Which makes it very difficult in the U.S. We don't have an " AA " for gun fanatics and need one badly.
